title: 111_hr4070
content: Reform of biodiesel income tax incentives under Section 40A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to focus on biodiesel production. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code is $1.00 per gallon of biodiesel produced and sold for business use or retail sale. Small producers may qualify for an increased credit. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code is increased by 10 cents per gallon for eligible small biodiesel producers, limited to the first 15,000,000 gallons produced annually. The credit amount is reduced if other benefits are received under section 6426 or 6427(e). Biodiesel is defined as liquid fuel derived from biomass meeting registration requirements for fuels. The term "biodiesel" refers to liquid fuel derived from biomass that meets registration requirements for fuels and fuel additives set by the EPA and ASTM D6751. It does not include any liquid eligible for a credit under section 40. If biodiesel that received a credit is not used as fuel, a tax is imposed on the person equal to the applicable rate under subsection (a) multiplied by the number of gallons of biodiesel. No credit for biodiesel produced outside the United States for use as fuel outside the United States. United States includes any possession. For the purposes of this paragraph, the term 'United States' includes any possession of the United States. Biodiesel transfers from an IRS registered production facility to a terminal or refinery can claim a credit under certain conditions. An eligible small biodiesel producer is defined as a person with a biodiesel production capacity not exceeding 60,000,000 gallons. The biodiesel production limit is set at 60,000,000 gallons, with rules for aggregation within controlled groups and pass-thru entities. The Secretary may allocate productive capacity among multiple facility owners and prescribe regulations to prevent individuals from benefiting from more than 60,000,000 gallons of biodiesel or 15,000,000 gallons per year. Additionally, there are rules for allocating small biodiesel credits to cooperative patrons. The Secretary can allocate productive capacity among facility owners and regulate biodiesel limits. There are also rules for allocating small biodiesel credits to cooperative patrons based on business done. The organization must make an irrevocable election on a timely filed return for the taxable year. The election requires a written notice to patrons during the payment period. Any unapportioned credit is included in the organization's taxable year amount. Patrons receive their portion of the credit. The organization must make an irrevocable election on a timely filed return for the taxable year. Patrons receive their portion of the credit in the first taxable year ending on or after the payment period or after receiving notice from the cooperative. Special rules apply for any decrease in credits for the taxable year. The organization must make an irrevocable election on a timely filed return for the taxable year. If the credit determined is less than shown on the return, the excess amount not apportioned to patrons will increase the tax imposed on the organization. This increase is not considered tax for determining any credit under this chapter.
